profile_data.summary:
AI-ML Professional | MS in Computer Science | Published Author | Research Enthusiast

Greetings! I'm an Applied Scientist II at Microsoft. I pursued MS in Computer Science from the University of Massachusetts Amherst. Prior to that, I have 4 years of research and industry experience developing and deploying Computer Vision, Natural Language Processing, Machine Learning and Generative AI based solutions to the cloud. I have spearheaded several AI projects for diverse sectors like telecom, healthcare, geomatics, finance, and retail during my work experience at Ericsson, Accenture and EXL. 

As a Graduate Research Assistant at Microsoft MAIDAP, I contributed to the NLP research, devising Parameter Efficient Fine-Tuning strategies (PEFT) for language encoders. This work got accepted at the EMNLP'23 conference. It holds considerable promise as it enhances the efficiency and effectiveness of language encoders, ultimately advancing the capabilities of NLP and Large language Models (LLMs). 

I cherished a desire to publish my work and with persistence, two of my papers got accepted at the CCVPR 2021 conference in the Computer Vision space and got published by Springer. My interest in AI goes beyond my professional boundaries and fuels my participation and engagement in other intellectual proceedings. I won the first position in Global AI Hackathon at Accenture across 18 countries. Besides research, I also foster a passion for teaching the underserved. I have taken several sessions on Python and Adobe Photoshop for High School students under my tech start-up ‘Design Dockyard’ wherein I provided design services besides developing mobile applications and websites.

AI's potential to improve lives is immense, but we must build ethical AI systems to safeguard humanity. With technical expertise, research skills, and a passion for service, I aim to leverage AI for the greater good and utilize the best of the diverse ways of thinking for the betterment of the world.

experience.description:
1. Developed and optimized a new summarizer model named "Mockingbird", designed to work after Vectara's existing retriever (Boomerang) and re-ranker (Multilingual Reranker v1) models. I was responsible for its training and evaluation, comparing its performance against SOTA models like GPT-4, Gemini 1.5 Pro, Mistral 7B Instruct, Llama 3 8B and Command R+ across multiple multilingual datasets. 
2. Contributed to the "Vectara Ingest" open-source project on GitHub by developing a Google Drive crawler to identify non-restricted files and retrieve information from them efficiently. This work involved integrating the Google Drive source into the existing data ingestion framework, which already supported websites, RSS feeds, Jira, Slack, Notion, and Docusaurus, thereby enhancing the platform's data retrieval capabilities.
3. Co-authored technical blog posts, on the "Mockingbird" model and "Top Large Language Models (LLMs)".

publications.name: DermPrompt - A Systematic Exploration of Prompt Engineering with GPT-4V for Dermatological Diagnosis
publications.description:
Accepted at NAACL-ClinicalNLP workshop 2024
This paper presents our team's participation in the MEDIQA-ClinicalNLP2024 shared task B. We present a novel approach to diagnosing clinical dermatology cases by integrating large multimodal models, specifically leveraging the capabilities of GPT-4V under a retriever and a re-ranker framework. Our investigation reveals that GPT-4V, when used as a retrieval agent, can accurately retrieve the correct skin condition 85% of the time using dermatological images and brief patient histories. Additionally, we empirically show that Naive Chain-of-Thought (CoT) works well for retrieval while Medical Guidelines Grounded CoT is required for accurate dermatological diagnosis. Further, we introduce a Multi-Agent Conversation (MAC) framework and show its superior performance and potential over the best CoT strategy. The experiments suggest that using naive CoT for retrieval and multi-agent conversation for critique-based diagnosis, GPT-4V can lead to an early and accurate diagnosis of dermatological conditions. The implications of this work extend to improving diagnostic workflows, supporting dermatological education, and enhancing patient care by providing a scalable, accessible, and accurate diagnostic tool.

publications.name: On Surgical Fine-Tuning for Language Encoders
publications.description:
Accepted at EMNLP 2023.
Fine-tuning all the layers of a pre-trained neural language encoder (either using all the parameters or using parameter-efficient methods) is often the de-facto way of adapting it to a new task. We show evidence that for different downstream language tasks, fine-tuning only a subset of layers is sufficient to obtain performance that is close to and often better than fine-tuning all the layers in the language encoder. We propose an efficient metric based on the diagonal of the Fisher information matrix (FIM score), to select the candidate layers for selective fine-tuning. We show, empirically on GLUE and SuperGLUE tasks and across distinct language encoders, that this metric can effectively select layers leading to a strong downstream performance. Our work highlights that task-specific information corresponding to a given downstream task is often localized within a few layers, and tuning only those is sufficient for strong performance. Additionally, we demonstrate the robustness of the FIM score to rank layers in a manner that remains constant during the optimization process.

publications.name: Understanding Code Semantics: An Evaluation of Transformer Models in Summarization
publications.description:
Accepted at GenBench, EMNLP 2023.
This paper delves into the intricacies of code summarization using advanced transformer-based language models. Through empirical studies, we evaluate the efficacy of code summarization by altering function and variable names to explore whether models truly understand code semantics or merely rely on textual cues. We have also introduced adversaries like dead code and commented code across three programming languages (Python, Javascript, and Java) to further scrutinize the model's understanding. Ultimately, our research aims to offer valuable insights into the inner workings of transformer-based LMs, enhancing their ability to understand code and contributing to more efficient software development practices and maintenance workflows.

publications.name: Borderless Table Detection and Extraction in Scanned Documents
publications.description:
Published by Springer @SAMDE'21 | Accepted at CCVPR 2021
In this paper, we have presented an end-to-end solution for borderless table detection and data extraction from scanned input documents with a 2 step process -
1. Table detection - This is done using a custom-trained deep learning model. 
2. Data extraction - This is done using OpenCV-based techniques to determine the row-column relationship and thus the data gets extracted in a structured way.

publications.name: Floor Space Optimisation And Recommendation System in 2D Space
publications.description:
Published by Springer @SAMDE'21 | Accepted at CCVPR 2021
In our paper, we presented an end-to-end solution for empty floor space calculation and recommendation system. Using Computer Vision techniques, various objects in the images get segmented, and later the empty space area gets classified into restricted and non-restricted zones. A restricted area is one that should be kept empty for people to move around easily. We finally use the non-restricted areas to provide balcony garden design recommendations.
